availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Thomas E. Bramlette: Governor's official correspondence file, petitions for pardons, remissions, and respites 1863-1867

body.p: W. B. Baker has deposited Bond in this Office to obtain Coffee House License from the Trustees of the town of R. Spring,
E. Ledford has deposited Bond in this Office with view of obtaining Coffee House License from the Trustees of the town of R Springs

I J. H. Wilkinson Presiding Judge of the Trigg County Court certify that at the time when Messr Ledford & Baker made application for License as stated in the foregoing petition, the opinion was entertained & acted ^upon^ by myself & the then clerk of the County Court Mat McKinney that it was only necessary for the applicant to procure "Merchants License to retail" for which the tax is five dollars -- instead of State License. The same opinion was entertained by members of the bar at this place. Acting upon these views we did issue the wrong License to Ledford & Baker, it was through our mistake as to the law, and not through any fault of theirs that the law was violated

Given under my hand this 15th day of Sept 1866
J. H. Wilkinson P. J TCC
